quoteFirst: On the left flank, since the 23rd Brigade had been held up on the German first line, the troops of the 25th, who had captured the village, had to face north in order to enfilade the enemy still holding out against the 23rd. It was through this pressure as well as through the redirection of the guns, that these Germans still on that part of the first line were
quoteTime: about eleven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: dislodged.
title: The Battles in Flanders, from Ypres to Neuve Chapelle
author: Dane, Edmund (Military historian)

quoteLast: she was in the lounge taking tea after the pleasant and refreshing custom of the country.  Mrs Cork and some gambling cronies were bridging as usual at another table, and there were various people scattered about, reading and gossiping.

author: Stockley, Cynthia, 1883-1936

quoteFirst: ), which was by no means uncomfortably warm. Passing Junction-House Ranch and Frémont Slough--whisky-shops both--we halted for “dinner,”
quoteLast: , at Frémont Springs, so called from an excellent little water behind the station. The building is of a style peculiar to the South, especially Florida--two huts connected by a roofwork of thatched timber, which acts as the best and coolest of verandas.
title: The City of the Saints, and Across the Rocky Mountains to California
author: Burton, Richard Francis, Sir, 1821-1890

title: Indian Fights and Fighters: The Soldier and the Sioux

quoteFirst: An artillery sergeant was mortally wounded this morning in the Redan. Enemy fired a salute of some forty guns
quoteLast: A Seikh sowar of the 3rd Irregular Cavalry deserted to the enemy this morning. The Bhoosa stack fell down to-day, burying ten or twelve bullocks; which, after much labour, were got out.
title:
The Defence of Lucknow
A Diary Recording the Daily Events during the Siege of the European Residency, from 31st May to 25th September, 1857
author: Wilson, T. F. (Thomas Fourness)

quoteFirst: It was the custom in the houses of the country-gentlemen to retire after dinner, which generally took place
quoteLast: , to the garden-bower or an arbour in the orchard, in order to partake of the banquet or dessert; thus Shallow, addressing Falstaffe after dinner, exclaims, "Nay, you shall see mine orchard: where, in an _arbour_, we will eat a last year's pippin of my own graffing, with a dish of carraways, and so forth.
title:
Shakspeare and His Times [Vol. 1 of 2]
Including the Biography of the Poet; criticisms on his genius and writings; a new chronology of his plays; a disquisition on the on the object of his sonnets; and a history of the manners, customs, and amusements, superstitions, poetry, and elegant literature of his age
author: Drake, Nathan, 1766-1836

quoteFirst: The first evidence I had of his renewed activity appeared when I returned to the chambers at
quoteTime: about eleven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , to find Polton hovering dejectedly about the sitting-room, apparently perpetrating as near an approach to a "spring clean" as could be permitted in a bachelor establishment.
title: The Red Thumb Mark
author: Freeman, R. Austin (Richard Austin), 1862-1943

quoteFirst: By means of these placards, and handbills to the same effect, a mob of over a thousand was collected in Mark Lane by nine a.m., and their number was doubled in another hour. They hissed and pelted the corn factors; but,
quoteLast: , when they began to break windows, the Lord Mayor appeared upon the spot. In vain he assured them that their behaviour could in no way affect the market.
title: The History of Bread: From Pre-historic to Modern Times
author: Ashton, John, 1834-1911

quoteFirst: Kolin, Czaslau (Chotusitz), Elbe Teinitz,--here in this Kladrup region, your Majesty is driving amid poor Villages which will be very famous by and by. And Prag itself will be doubly famed in war, if your Majesty knew it, and the Ziscaberg be of bloodier memory than the Weissenberg itself!--His Majesty, the morrow's sun having risen upon Nimburg, rolls into Prag successfully
quoteLast: , Hill of Zisca not disturbing him; goes to the Klein-Seite Quarter, where an Aulic Councillor with fine Palace is ready; all the cannon thundering from the walls at his Majesty's advent; and Prince Eugenio, the ever-present, being there to receive his Majesty,--and in fact to invite him to dinner this day at half-past twelve. It is Friday, 1st of August, 1732.
title: History of Friedrich II of Prussia — Volume 09
author: Carlyle, Thomas, 1795-1881

quoteFirst: While these events were transpiring on our right, the enemy, in formidable numbers, made repeated and desperate assaults upon the left of our line.
quoteLast: , having massed his troops under cover of the houses of Fredericksburg, he moved forward in strong columns to seize Marye's and Willis's Hills. All his batteries on the Stafford Heights directed their fire upon the positions occupied by our artillery, with a view to silence it, and cover the movement of the infantry.
title: The Rise and Fall of the Confederate Government, Volume 2
author: Davis, Jefferson, 1808-1889

quoteFirst: The garrisons of the strong points located the enemy by means of patrols, so that when the fog lifted at

quoteFirst: My other dog, "Bull," died on Sunday, so here I am alone, 150 miles from any white man.  Once more passed the night smoking on my waggon-box, the only thing that I could do, and
quoteLast: , on Tuesday 23rd, as I was lying down in my waggon, I caught the sound of oxen's feet on the road, which proved to be mine, with my driver and forelooper bringing them on, and holding up a can to show me they had water.
title: Twenty-Five Years in a Waggon in South Africa: Sport and Travel in South Africa
author: Anderson, Andrew A.

quoteFirst: The guilty, wretched man, thus doomed to be the victim to appease the rage of the mob, in a quarter of an hour was led out bareheaded by the servants of the tzar to the market-place. The mob fell upon him with clubs, beat him to the earth, dragged him over the pavements, and finally cut off his head. Thus satiated,
quoteTime: about eleven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: they dispersed and returned to their homes.
title: The Empire of Russia: From the Remotest Periods to the Present Time
author: Abbott, John S. C. (John Stevens Cabot), 1805-1877
